developers/intro.title: Introduction
developers/intro.description: Serpent OS employs some techniques and technologies that require further documentation in order for other developers to not only understand our ecosystem, but extend it.

developers/stone/header.title: Header
developers/stone/header.description: Stone archives are encoded with a version agnostic header, ensuring that version-specific

developers/stone/overview.title: Overview
developers/stone/overview.description: Serpent OS uses a custom binary format for the distribution of packages, aka the .stone format.

developers/stone/v1/header.title: Header
developers/stone/v1/header.description: The v1 header contains 3 fields to denote the type of the .stone file as well as a count

packaging/boulder.title: Boulder
packaging/boulder.description: boulder is the Serpent OS build tool, and used to build packages. Make sure you have the latest

packaging/intro.title: Introduction
packaging/intro.description: These docs are brand new and quite pathetic atm.

packaging/recipes/build_deps.title: Build dependencies
packaging/recipes/build_deps.description: Every build of a recipe by boulder will create an entirely new root, with only the absolute minimum support dependencies in place.

packaging/recipes/metadata.title: Metadata
packaging/recipes/metadata.description: Recipes provide basic metadata to support discovery and automation.

packaging/recipes/overview.title: Overview
packaging/recipes/overview.description: Simply put, a recipe is some metadata to describe a software package, and the associated instructions required to build that package in a reproducible fashion. Doing so allows us to automate builds, and provide software updates. At a surface level, our stone.yml recipe format

packaging/recipes/package_definition.title: Package definitions
packaging/recipes/package_definition.description: A recipe build can result in a number of packages being produced from a single source, through an automatic splitting system. Certain subpackages are already defined in the boulder project to ensure consistency of package splitting and names, whereas some may be explicitly defined in a recipe to fine-tune the results.

packaging/recipes/upstreams.title: Upstreams
packaging/recipes/upstreams.description: The majority of packages are built using upstream release sources. While it is possible to create packages manually from local assets, the bulk of packages take an upstream tarball and build it.
